issues.title: Add scoping support in X.509 chain
issues.author: gnarea
issues.body:
The X.509 certification chain should be allowed to narrow down what's allowed in the signature metadata and plaintext:

- Service OID. A new critical (yet optional) X.509 extension could be used to restrict the service in which signatures may be bound. Since the service OID may be specified in the TXT record, it may be set in zero-to-many certificates, and it must be set in the signature metadata, all OIDs must match, or else the signature bundle will fail validation.
- Member attribution. If the SignedData signer is a member, and the member attribution field in the signature metadata is specified, then they must match, or else verification will fail.
- Service-specific metadata. A new critical (yet optional) X.509 extension could be used to restrict how the service can be used, using a key/value map whose keys and values are entirely service-dependant. For example, Kliento could use this to restrict where tokens can be used (the "audience").

issues.title: Add Privacy Considerations
issues.author: gnarea
issues.body:
For example, we require the organisation to have its own certificate, whose public key is referenced in the TXT record, so that it can issue member certificates without leaking information about the users, or information that can be used to enumerate users.

See also:

- https://authors.ietf.org/en/recommended-content
- https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc6973/

issues.title: Require ability to customise DNSSEC trust anchors
issues.author: gnarea
issues.body:
Recommend IANA's as the only trust anchors for interoperability and security, but allow alternative roots since it doesn't make a difference to us.

Primary use cases:

- Local testing. For example, we generate alternative DNS roots in the unit tests of VeraId Authority, so we can exercise the entire protocol without mocking the VeraId JavaScript Library.
- Rotate IANA's public key digests before the underlying DNSSEC implementation updates its own copy of the digests.

As the author, I should caution that I advise against alternative DNS roots, but I see no technical reason to ban them. See: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc2826
